Achieving an efficient La3Si8N11O4: Eu2þ phosphor via chemical reduction of nano-scale carbon film: Toward white light-emitting diodes

a b s t r a c t
In this work, Eu-doped La3Si8N11O4 phosphors with different doping concentrations are fabricated by solid state reaction method. A broad and asymmetric emission band that covers the wavelength range of 425e550 nm is observed. X-ray diffraction Rietveld refinement and X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) analyses reveal the co-existence of both trivalent and divalent states of Eu. By coating the phosphor particles with an ultrathin carbon layer using CVD technique, followed by an annealing in N2 at 1600 C, the trivalent ions Eu3þ are reduced to Eu2þ, resulting in a significant enhancement of quantum efficiency, both internal and external, and absorption efficiency. The application of the La3Si8N11O4:Eu in white light-emitting diodes is tested by coating the phosphor onto a near-UV LED chip in combination with the red-, green- and blue-emitting phosphors ([Ca, Sr]AlSiN3:Eu, ®-Sialon:Eu and BaMgAl10O17:Eu, respectively). It is demonstrated that the presence of the La3Si8N11O4:Eu phosphor significantly enhances the color rendering index of the device, showing its great potential for wLEDs applications.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Owing to the advantages of low energy consumption, high efficiency, environmental friendliness, and long life-time, white light emitting diodes (wLEDs) are considered as the next-generation of lighting devices. In the market, wLEDs are commonly fabricated by combining a yellow YAG: Ce3þ phosphor with a blue LED chip, which shows the poor color rendering properties due to low red region emission of YAG: Ce3þ [1]. In an alternative approach, a near-

UV LED chip is coated with full-spectrum covered phosphors which consist of blue, green and red-emitting phosphors. The wLEDs fabricated using this method exhibit superior color rendering properties.
As the light converted material, phosphor is the core element that determines the efficiency of wLEDs devices. Therefore, various phosphors have been investigated for application in wLEDs, including aluminate, silicate and fluoride based phosphors [2e10]. Recently, luminescent ions doped (oxy)nitride phosphors have received enormous attention due to their adjustable emission color, high luminescence efficiency, and rigid lattice network. A variety of (oxy)nitride phosphors have been successfully developed and partly commercialized in wLEDs applications, including a-Sialon: Ce3þ, b-Sialon: Eu2þ, (Ca, Sr, Ba)2Si5N8: Eu2þ, (Ca, Sr)AlSiN3: Eu2þ
and SrLiAl3N4: Eu2þ [11]. So far, phosphors in the Ln Si N O system, such as La3Si8N11O4:Ce, La5Si3O12N:Ce, La4SiO7N2:Ce, LaSiO2N:Ce, Y5Si3O12N:Ce, Y4Si2O7N2:Ce, YSiO2N:Ce and Y2Si3O3N4:Ce, are investigated intensively because they emit blue or blue-to-green light under near-UV light excitation and could be used in full spectrum covered wLEDs [12e14]. Among them, La3Si8N11O4:Ce exhibits a blue emission centered at 430 nm under UV excitation and less thermal quenching compared with other La Si N O Ce phosphors such as La5Si3NO12: Ce3þ and LaSiNO2: Ce3þ. In addition, its emission spectrum can be tuned to green region by doping Eu into the La3Si8N11O4 host lattice, i.e., La3Si8N11O4: Eu2þ, covering the spectral range of 460e530 nm. Under the 320 nm excitation, La3Si8N11O4: Eu2þ shows high internal quantum efficiency (IQE) and external quantum efficiency (EQE), which can reach to 44% and 33%, respectively [15]. These properties demonstrate La3Si8N11O4: Eu2þ as a promising candidate for wLEDs applications. Nevertheless, to promote its practical use in wLEDs devices, a further improvement of quantum efficiency (QE) and an insight into the luminescent mechanisms are essentially needed. In this work, we investigate the microstructure evolution of La3Si8N11O4:Eu2þ phosphor upon increasing Eu concentration. A novel strategy to increase its QE by effectively reducing Eu3þ to Eu2þ is developed. The microstructure, Eu valence states, PL properties and the mechanisms of its improved properties are discussed in detail.

sections.heading: 2.1. Material synthesis
sections.text: La3-xSi8N11O4: xEu2þ (x¼ 1e7%, LSON 1e7 hereafter) phosphors were prepared by solid-state reaction in a Boron Nitride (BN) crucible. Si3N4 (Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd. Shanghai, China), La2O3 (Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd. Shanghai, China), LaN (lab-made), EuN (lab-made) were manually mixed using a mortar and pestle in a nitrogen-filled glovebox (H2O< 1 ppm, O2< 1 ppm). The powders were annealed in N2 atmosphere at 1750 C for 4 h. The sintered powders were then finely grounded in air using a mortar and pestle. Finally, the carbon coating on the surface of La3xSi8N11O4: xEu2þ (x¼ 3, 7%) was performed by chemical vapor deposition (CVD) at 700 C using a gas mixture of N2 (gas flow rate: 100mL/min) and C2H2 (gas flow rate: 20mL/min). The reaction time was kept for 30 s. Then the carbon-coated powder La3xSi8N11O4: xEu2þ (x¼ 3, 7%) (LSON3@C, LSON7@C) was taken out and heat-treated in a BN crucible at 1600 C for 2 h in N2 atmosphere (LSON3@C-1600 C, LSON7@C-1600 C). The obtained powders were milled in Si3N4 mortar by hand for further measurements.

sections.heading: 2.2. Material characterization
sections.text:
The phase formation was analyzed by X-ray diffraction (XRD; Model 7000, SHIMADZU, Japan) using Cu Ka radiation at a scanning rate of 2 /min. Rietveld refinements of the X-ray diffractograms were conducted using the GSAS (General Structure Analysis System) program [16]. The microstructure was observed by using High-Resolution Transmission Electron Microscopy equipped with Energy Dispersion X-ray (EDX) spectrometer (HRTEM; 2100F, JEOL, Tokyo, Japan). The amount of residual carbon was tested by high frequency infrared carbon-sulfur analyzer (EA-CSA-05, U-THERM INTERNATIONAL (H.K.) Ltd, China). The X-ray absorption spectra at the Eu L3-edge were measured at the beamline of BL14W1 Shanghai Synchrotron Radiation Facility. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis of samples was performed on an ESCALAB250 X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (Thermo-VG
Scientific, USA) using monochromatized Al Ka radiation source (1486.92 eV).

sections.heading: 2.3. Luminescence properties
sections.text: Photoluminescence spectra (PL) were measured by a fluorescence spectrophotometer (Model F-4600, Hitachi, Tokyo, Japan) with a 200W Xe lamp as an excitation source. The emission spectra were corrected for the spectral response of themonochromator and photomultiplier tube (R928P, Hamamatsu Photonics K.K., Hamamatsu, Japan) by a light diffuser and a tungsten lamp (Noma Electric Corp., New York, USA; 10 V, 4 A). The photoluminescence excitation (PLE) spectra were also corrected for the spectral distribution of the Xe lamp intensity by measuring Rhodamine-B as a reference. The luminescence spectra for QE measurements and the absorption efficiency were recorded using an intensified multichannel spectrometer (MCPD-7000, Otsuka Electronics, Japan). The data of BaSO4 were used as the reference for calibration. The optical parameters of the fabricated wLEDs devices were measured by using an integrating sphere spectroradiometer system (LHS-1000, Everfine Co., Hangzhou, China).

sections.heading: 3.1. La3Si8N11O4:Eu
sections.text:
Originally reported by Grins et al., La3Si8N11O4 crystal has C2/c orthorhombic structure, with lattice parameters of a¼ 15.850 Å, b¼ 4.9029 Å, c¼ 18.039 Å, respectively [17]. Present structure refinement starts from the known data. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of LSON1-7 powders indicate the single phase. Rietveld Refinement results are shown in Fig. 1. The refined details can be found in Tables S1eS4 (Supporting Information). The results show that the C2/c orthorhombic crystal structure remained for all Eu concentrations. However, the lattice parameters a and b exhibit a decreasing trend with increasing Eu concentration, whereas c is nearly unaffected (shown in Fig. 1-b).
Based on the refined lattice parameters, the crystal structure of LSON3 is drawn in Fig. 2, which contains ribbons as structural units with the composition of Si6(O, N)14. Four types of Si(O, N)4 tetrahedron are present in La3Si8N11O4, i.e., [SiN4], [SiON3], [SiON3] and [SiN2O2]. There are two different La occupancy sites, where the La1 atom is octahedral coordinated to 4 O/N and 2 O atoms at a distances of 2.47e2.74 Å, and the La2 atom coordinated to 5 O/N, 2 O, and 1 N atoms at a distances of 2.50e3.00 Å. Luminescent Eu ions are expected to substitute La ions due to their similar radii. Eu ions occupy La1 and La2 sites equally, which results in the discrepant luminescent properties.
The PL spectra of LSON1-7 are shown in Fig. 3-a, b. Under 330 nm excitation, La3Si8N11O4: xEu2þ phosphors exhibit an emission band covering the 425e550 nm range, centered at ~480 nm, which is assigned to the 5d 4f electronic transitions of Eu2þ. The PL intensity reaches its maximum at x¼ 3%. The emission spectra show a red shift as increasing Eu concentration, which shifts the emission color from cyan to green region (Fig. 3-c, d). The increased Eu concentration reduces the distance between Eu ions and causes splitting of 5d orbitals of Eu. The probability of energy transfer from higher 5d level to lower one increases, therefore lowering the emission energy for transfer from the low 5d excited state to the 4f ground state, which consequently shifts the emission to longer wavelength [18,19].
It can be noted that the emission spectra show an asymmetric characteristic, which can be divided into two bands by Gaussian fitting, as seen in Fig. 3-b. As known, the 5d energy level splitting of Eu2þ is strongly dependent on the local crystal-field. According to
field splitting (CFS) theory, the crystal field that central ions suffer can be expressed as Dq¼ 35Ze/4R5, where Z, e and R represent the valence of anions, elementary charge and average coordinating distance, respectively. Therefore, the longer Eu-O(N) distance creates the weaker crystal field, leading to the higher energy emission. The high energy emission band can be assigned to Eu occupancy at the larger La2 site, and the other to Eu at La1 site. Because of the similarity of their ionic radii, the Eu2þ ions are expected to randomly occupy at both La1 and La2 sites in the Eu-doped La3Si8N11O4 crystal. As demonstrated by the Gaussian fitting results, the high and low energy emission bands are almost balanced
as increasing the Eu concentration. Therefore, it is believed that doped Eu ions reside at La1 and La2 sites equally, which is consistent with the XRD Rietveld refinement results.

sections.heading: 3.2. La3Si8N11O4:Eu with carbon coating and annealing
sections.text:
As mentioned above, La3 xSi8N11O4:xEu phosphors exhibit a broad cyan emission band, indicating the existence of Eu2þ ionic state. However, the lattice parameters exhibit a decreasing trend with increasing the Eu concentration. This is controversy to the ionic radius value when Eu2þ(1.17Å, 6CN)/La3þ (1.032Å, 6CN)
substitution happens [20]. Considering the radius of Eu3þ(0.947, 6CN) is smaller than that of La3þ(1.032Å, 6CN), and Eu3þ seems to favorably replace La3þ ions because of the charge balance, it can be expected that both Eu2þ and Eu3þ (0.947Å, 6CN) are substituted for La3þ ions in La3Si8N11O4 lattice. The synergistic effect of mixed Eu2þ and Eu3þ residence can result in the decrease of the lattice parameters, depending on the Eu2þ/Eu3þ ratio. The presence of a large amount of Eu3þ in La3 xSi8N11O4: xEu is demonstrated in the XANES spectrum, which will be discussed later.
The existence of Eu3þ ionic state lowers the quantum efficiency of the La3 xSi8N11O4: xEu phosphor. Therefore, in an attempt to increase the quantum efficiency, the reduction of Eu3þ to Eu2þ is highly needed. Various approaches including carbon coating and post-annealing were adopted. As designed, performing post heattreatment of carbon-coated LSON7 (LSON7@C) phosphors in an inert atmosphere can result in a strong reducing effect, converting the Eu3þ residual to Eu2þ ions as described by Equation (1) [21].
This increases the Eu2þ luminescent centers and hence PL intensity. Here, we choose La3 xSi8N11O4: xEu (x¼ 3%, 7%) as an example.
Eu2O3 þC/2EuOþ CO (1) As demonstrated by the STEM and HRTEM images of the LSON3@C and LSON7@C (Fig. 4-a, b, d, e), a thin carbon layer with a thickness of ~1.3 nm is deposited on the surface of phosphor particles. No crystal fringes ascribed to carbon are observed, indicating its amorphous state. Further EDS-mapping analyses in Fig. 4-g provide the elemental distribution of La, Si and C, proving the carbon accumulation on the particle surface. Performing postannealing on LSON3@C and LSON7@C in N2 atmosphere results in the disappearance of the deposited carbon. An amount of residual carbon of 0.057wt% was determined by high frequency infrared carbon-sulfur analyzer. Such a small amount of carbon will not affect PL properties of phosphors. The annealed samples (Fig. 4-c, f)
show an anomalous surface microstructure by displaying obvious stacking faults. The stacking faults produce domains across several nanometers close to the surface. This could arise from the reduction reaction between C and the host at high temperature.
Due to the larger ion radius of Eu2þ (1.17 Å, 6CN) than that of Eu3þ (0.947 Å, 6CN), the Eu3þ/Eu2þ transitions can result in an expansion of the crystal lattice of La3Si8N11O4: Eu2þ. The expansion is confirmed by XRD Rietveld Refinement performed on LSON3@C1600 and LSON7@C-1600 powders shown in Fig. 5-a, b. The refined details can be found in Tables S5eS6. The summary of lattice parameter changes is drawn in Fig. 5-c, d. Compared with the value in LSON3 and LSON7, it is seen that crystal lattice constants of LSON3@C-1600 and LSON7@C-1600 increase, except for the lattice constant c of LSON3. After post-annealing, the lattice constants a, b and c increase from 15.7822, 4.8665,17.9640 Å in LSON7 to 15.8027, 4.8714, 17.9753 Å in LSON7@C-1600, respectively.
In Fig. 6-a, LSON3@C and LSON7@C particles exhibit a grey color with low luminescence intensity, due to the light absorption of deposited carbon. The appearance of LSON3@C-1600 and LSON7@C-1600 shifts to white again and give a strong cyan emission, which further confirms the reduction reaction between carbon and the host. Eu LIII-edge XANES measurements of LSON7 and LSON7@C-1600 are performed to clarify the Eu valence transition, shown in Fig. 6-b. Two peaks at 6976 and 6982 eV are attributed to the divalent and trivalent ionic states of Eu, respectively [22]. In addition to Eu2þ ions, a large amount of Eu3þ is
present in La3 xSi8N11O4: xEu possibly because of the matched charge balance between Eu3þ and La3þ. After post-annealing (LSON7@C-1600), the intensity of the Eu3þ peak significantly decreases whereas that of the Eu2þ increases. The XANES results indicate that the reduction of Eu3þ to Eu2þ is achieved by using carbon as a reducing agent at high temperature. The reduction effect is also confirmed by using high resolution XPS spectra of Eu 3d shown in Fig. S1. The Eu 3d spectra can be divided into two groups 3d3/2 and 3d5/2, respectively, owing to the spin-orbit interaction of the Eu 3d core level. For the LSON7, Eu3þ ions are dominated. In contrast, it is found that relative intensity of Eu2þ is much stronger than that of Eu3þ in LSON7@C-1600. The increase of luminescent Eu2þ ions results in the increase of PL intensity. As seen in Fig. 6-c, the PL intensity reaches the value of 192% and 148% in LSON3@C1600 and LSON7@C-1600, compared with the original ones in LSON3 and LSON7, respectively.
A schematic representation is drawn to illustrate the mechanism of the enhanced emission intensity in Eu doped La3Si8N11O4 phosphors, as shown in Fig. 7-a. The higher concentration of Eu3þ ions lowers the PL intensity in LSON. The increase of Eu2þ content due to the reduction effect results in the significantly stronger PL intensity that achieved in LSON3@C-1600 and LSON7@C-1600 phosphors. Consequently, monitored at 330 nm, the internal quantum efficiency (IQE), external quantum efficiency (EQE) and absorption efficiency dramatically increased from 45, 30, 67% in LSON3 to 68, 49, 73% in LSON3@C-1600, respectively.

sections.heading: 3.3. wLEDs device fabricated by treated La3Si8N11O4:Eu phosphor
sections.text: In order to verify the promising application of treated La3Si8N11O4:Eu phosphor, a wLEDs device is fabricated by combining LSON3@C-1600, blue BaMgAl10O17:Eu (BAM, lem¼ 453 nm), green b-Sialon:Eu (lem¼ 533 nm) and red (Ca, Sr) AlSiN3:Eu (lem¼ 630 nm) phosphors with an UV-LED chip. The optical properties and a photo of the fabricated wLEDs device are presented (Fig. 7-b, c, d). The wLEDs device shows bright white color with chromaticity coordinates (0.3459, 0.3486) and a color temperature of 4958 K. The color rendering index (Ra) reaches as high as 93.2. Comparably, a wLEDs device without LSON3@C-1600 shows a Ra¼ 86.8, chromatic coordinates (0.3458, 0.3467) and a color temperature of 4947 K. The Ra is lower due to the lack of bluegreen component in the spectrum. These results demonstrate the potential applications in wLEDs of the treated La3Si8N11O4:Eu phosphors.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
In conclusion, we have employed the solid state reaction method to synthesize La3Si8N11O4:Eu phosphors with various dopant concentrations (i.e., 1e7%). The photoluminescence shows a broad and asymmetric emission band that covers the 425e550 nm wavelength range. The XRD Rietveld Refinement and the X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) measurements demonstrate that both Eu2þ and Eu3þ ionic states exist in the La3Si8N11O4 host lattice. A two-step process has been developed for the reduction of Eu3þ to Eu2þ, including the coating of the phosphor particles by a thin carbon layer using CVD technique, followed by the annealing in N2 ambient at 1600 C. Owing to their strong reducing nature, during the annealing step the carbon atoms reduce the trivalent Eu3þ ions to the divalent Eu2þ, as evidenced by XANES and XPS characterizations. The Eu3þ/Eu2þ transition results in the higher emission intensity and increases the internal quantum efficiency (IQE), external quantum efficiency (EQE) and
absorption efficiency from 45, 30, 67% in LSON3 to 68, 49, 73%, respectively. The application of the synthesized phosphor inwLEDs was tested, which was performed on the sample with an Eu doping concentration of 3% after carbon coating and annealing (LSON3@C1600). The results show that the presence of LSON3@C-1600 considerably improves the color rendering index of the wLEDs in comparison with the device without this phosphor.
